Dear Graydon:
I appreciate your note of March 27, Personally, I think the
roast beef is an ideal luncheon dish. However, I certainly think
that fish ought to be available sinoe it is Friday.
We are doing everything possible to get enough money to handle
the NAEB Board meeting. At the moment, we just don’t have the funds.
Furthermore, most people come to the IER meeting on their own budgets.
Obviously, if funds are available by May 1 ( and I am doing everything
I can to see that they are), the Board will authorize reimbursement
for travel.
Insofar as your Oram and ^ich comments are concerned, the general
understanding is that NAEB will receive at least $2000 clear on any
$1000 that is paid to Oram and &ich. Oram, of course, is much more
optomistic, and feels that we will raise far more than the $25,000
(in the clear) during any one year.
'Hiere has not been any difficulty in the past two campaigns in
obtaining funds from Foundations, even though we were represented by
Oram and ^ich. Ihe technique is such that they do not even enter the
picture when it comes to direct negotiations. All of the work has
then to be done by yours truly.
You have, of course, heard the good news about Dick Hull. He
will be going to Washington as the paid chairman of JCET. Bob Hudson
has taken leave from Illinois and now is the paid consultant to the
Ford Foundation. All of this is as it should be, but I feel that
our best operating personnel is going to be stripped down.
I will be in touch with you as socaa as I have time to write in
detail. ft
